segments.text: Well, when I came on board, we had great difficulty getting people, honest astronomers, to look at the planets.
That changed when we had specific problems that were of interest to people, such as what is the actual surface pressure on Mars?
I remember it when IceBinRad came out with that number.
That was a bombshell because they had already started building probes for 85 millibar surface pressure.
Right.

When we started to pique the interest of astronomers with some specific problems, the astronomers started to use the techniques, the technologies that had been developed in the interim to look at the planets.
They had not, with the exception of a very few people.
Bill Sinton and company did the infrared.
They were doing spectra.
Kuiper was doing some work, but there were a very limited number of people.
But when a serious problem came along, and why did these astronomers pay attention to planetary problems?
Because NASA said, we are going to send spacecraft to these planets.
We are going to find out something.
Planets became of greater interest to the public, the universities,
and to the scientists.

And what we did in those areas was simply to say, if we had a problem such as, let's say, the surface pressure on Mars, bring together people that we thought might have some idea of how to approach the problem.
You know, bring them together in a big meeting.
Money was no problem in those days.
Say, here's the problem.
Here's what they told us in the past.
We just want you to think about the problem.
What we need is this."
And many of them went away and said, hey, I can think of a technique to give you that answer.
And the surface pressure of Mars was a very good example of that problem.
What do you think of the future of planetary astronomy?
Is it going downhill?
The answer to that is I think that the problems are becoming more difficult.
I think that the type of problems that interest most astronomers are no longer relevant in the planetary area, but I think that there are many problems that interest
related fields are becoming more important.
For example, there are things associated with, let's say, volcanology on Io that are becoming important, but most astronomers aren't interested in volcanology.
I think that there are a large number of problems that can be
worked on the planets that we didn't consider significant before because we didn't have the ground truth that has come as a result of the spacecraft.
But now that we know what's actually happening on a planet, we can go back and learn how to interpret our telescopic observations.
I think there's another area, and that is high resolution imaging, high resolution
infrared or spectroscopy, primarily infrared.
Because that's where the absorption bands of interest are.
Are, yeah.
I think that there are a lot of problems that are coming up that can be approached with new technologies, and we can do a lot of work on them.
For example, if we can get reasonably high-resolution images of
a planet like Jupiter.
There's a lot of meteorology that can be done on Jupiter.

In that line, I noticed that the CCD images they've taken of Mars really look like Mars does when you have a good telescope and a good site and a good night, and you see all this detail but never able to
photograph it because you couldn't beat the seeing in the old days.
And you get this variegated appearance which looks kind of strangely familiar to me, but it's just another example on a very obvious level of look what we can see.
And we've mentioned Jupiter with that sort of stuff where before it all had to be visual because they couldn't photograph it and make a permanent reference.
And the other thing is we didn't know what it was we were looking at.
of things that they saw on the surface, for example, of Jupiter, that they didn't know whether they were optical illusions or something actually there.
We know now, in many cases, there were features that were there which we can use as tracers.
But we are able to do things like three-tenths of an arc second at times with some of the telescopes, depending on the site.
But with new instrumentation, we may be able to do that well on a continuous basis, if not even a little better than that.
And if you can do that, there are a lot of problems that you can solve.
There's been a lot of talk for the last 10 or 20 years, as a matter of fact, about the practical importance of planetary astronomy.
The Earth is a planet.
And in the last couple of years, there's been a whole lot of attention, at least in the popular press,
to kill our asteroids and comets and things like that.
Do you think that's overdone, or do you think that we ought to try and get every buck we can?
Oh.
Again, it's purely a subjective opinion question, but there's no objective way of answering it.
No, I think that some of these things are important to study.
I don't think, for example, killer asteroids, they say that the ones that are going to hit us and do some damage we will never even see.
And if you do see them, they'll be so close that you don't have any time to do anything about them.
But like everything else, I don't know of any situation where more knowledge has hurt us.
I know it gets a lot of popularity
some of these things.
But I think that there is some good, valid, beneficial use that comes from studying some of this stuff.
And the cost of studying it is negligible compared to the cost of a lot of other programs.
My concern is this, that if there is a demise of planetary or solar system exploration with spacecraft, it's going to be very difficult to try to get the
funds necessary to continue a significant program in planetary astronomy.
That brings up a point.
How much of an impact on funding do you think the fact that there is no evidence whatsoever of life on Mars has had?
That's a difficult question to answer.
If they would have found one organic molecule, do you think we would have had more probes?
The answer to that is probably not that much different.
I think we are still interested in pursuing examination of Mars for possible life forms.
I think that, you know, maybe not the way we did it with the Viking mission, but I think that there is still an interest there.
There certainly is an interest in Mars.
Now, if this creature on Mars keeps devouring our spacecraft and we quit, we might find out something.
That brings up a point.

The loss of the Mars Observer, from what I could tell, came as quite a shock to a lot of the scientists and engineers involved, but we both go back far enough to remember the sixties when Ranger One through Six failed their Air One family.
You'd think this was a
a useful, if you will, slap in the face at overconfident people?
Maybe, yes, but I think it's also a danger.
It's a very dangerous one.
You know, we've often said, does success bring success or does failure bring success?
And with success, I mean the latter part of that is more money.
more programs.
If you have a successful program, there's a tendency by the powers that be that says, well, you've learned what you wanted to learn.
Let's turn our efforts to something else.
And so when you have a failure, there's quite often the position that, gee, you know, it's too bad, but we should really follow up.
And we'll probably get another Mars mission for just that reason.
It may have been harder if this mission had been successful to get another Mars mission than if this had been a failure.
A good example of that is Space Telescope.
So it's hard to say.
I don't know, and this is sort of off the record,
are now saying, hey, you better look at plans for another Mars observer or one that can do part of the mission of Mars that Mars observer was for.
Nobody's canceled the measure pathfinder mission yet.
We're still going ahead with measure network.
So it hasn't brought an end to the program.
The thing that concerns me is that at the time when a space program
does come to an end, that the ground-based program, which is still capable of producing tremendous results, is probably going to lose funding as well.
And the ground-based stuff, of course, information comes much cheaper than anything.
There's no comparison.
Yes, that's one of the things I want to do.
There's been endless books written about all the wonderful things that Viking and Voyager have done, but most of our information on the planets still comes from the ground.
Would you agree?
Well, not really.
Of course, there's a lot of stuff we've never seen.
No.
The information that we got from the spacecraft, you cannot get any other way than from the spacecraft.
Which is the way it's supposed to be.
Which is the way it is supposed to be.
However, the fact that we've got all this good information from a spacecraft does not nullify the need for ground-based observations and, in fact, increases the value of ground-based observations.
Just thinking that now that we know...
Yes.
Excuse me.
I was just going to say that once you find out something from a spacecraft, you often find out that
really need a spacecraft.
I'm thinking of the great dark spot on Neptune.
Now that we know it's there, people are looking at old visual drawings of Neptune and finding it.
Oh, yes.
Well, that's it.
As soon as you know what the ground truth is, you don't necessarily have to keep repeating it.
Now, it is true that we would like to know at greater resolution what the surface looks like, but Jupiter is an excellent example.
We can study the
motions in the Jovian atmosphere features down to a certain size quite well from the ground.
And if you had something like the space telescope, extremely well.
The volcanic activity on Io is studied not continuously, but on quite a continuous basis from the Earth.
Look at comets.
Now that we know what a comet looks like,
and how the emissions from a comet take place, we can learn a lot more about comets from the ground than we were ever able to in the past.
The same thing, I'm sure, is going to be true about asteroids.
So the value of ground-based astronomy has not been diminished but has been increased.
Let me switch to a different topic
I've asked this because I was looking at this part of your records yesterday at the NASA history office, and there was a big funding crunch in 1973.
I mean, your budget had been going up, and then slam-bang, it started to go down.
What was that like?
Well, it was disaster, of course.
because many of the programs that were going along and growing had to be cut back.
Many less people were funded.
At that time, we started our abortion, if you will, of planetary astronomers, and I never really recovered from that.
So I'm trying to think of something that was specifically affected at that time.
Me.
Well, you was one thing.
But we did have some very severe cutbacks in NASA.
We had some severe cutbacks in what we could do.
One of the things, for example, that we wanted to do when we built the IRTF is to equip it with the best instrumentation possible.
Because of budget cuts, we had to stop building any instrumentation for it.
So what we're working with today
is last decade's instrumentation.
And it's very expensive to do it, because you're having to do stuff with the instrumentation that's not as good.
It takes far longer to do the job, and it just is not satisfactory.
It ends up by costing you much more money than it would if you could do it with today's technology.
Based on your experience, do you think that NASA in general
over-manages science, under-manages science, does it about right?
From a personal point of view, I think it depends very much on the type of program.
In the case of data analysis, I think we do it about right.
People write proposals.
The proposals are reviewed by their peers.
We fund one of them we can.
I think that there is some good work that we don't fund.
I think there's also some poor work that gets proposed by good scientists and sometimes does get funded, but that's the way the dice comes up.
But I think that there are programs where we are trying to look for new things that

money is wasted because the programs are not managed closely enough and i don't think in these cases that people are to blame many people go down the wrong path unknowingly because somebody isn't taking a look at it and saying hey wait a second is that really the way you want to go not that they want to be directed
But I think we have to stay on top of and take an overview of many things in order to do it properly.
I've heard a lot of comments that with flight missions in particular, NASA shows the pretty pictures and then chops off the data analysis.
What do you think about that?
We chop off the data analysis only when we cannot get any more money.
We are just, I have been responsible for the program.
Which is?
Neptune Data Analysis Program, and that's basically Voyager data analysis.
We are now in our fourth year of that, and that is after the first year or two in which the investigators were supported, and that's being funded at a level of on the order of $3 million a year.
Now, we would have liked to have funded it earlier for more money, let's say $5 million a year, $6 million a year, and done it.
I think there's still a lot of good data that can be taken out of it.
I think that there are gaps, and what I mean by gaps is this.
I personally have been heavily involved in the Voyager mission since I've been the Voyager program scientist for the Uranus and Neptune encounters.
We can know a lot more about Jupiter and Saturn today because of material we have learned about Uranus and Neptune.
We do not have a legitimate data analysis program on either Jupiter or Saturn or on the outer planets as a whole.
What we have a program for right now is to reduce the data that we got at Neptune.
But as a scientist, you can understand that something we learned at Neptune, they say to somebody, hey, wait a second.
If we do the same analysis on Uranus,
We're going to get some very important information out about Uranus and about the other planets in general.
We have to say to them, sorry, but unless you can tie it into Neptune, we can't support you under this program.
So there are areas where, I would say after the fact, you might want to come back and take a new look at some old data.
we have not always been able to do that because we just don't have the money in the programs.
Yeah, on interviewing myself when I was at headquarters, I really did run into the problem you did of having lots of money.
In fact, that's where the original idea came from to build the telescopes at Texas and Hawaii was that I guess Bob Bryson and somebody else had like four million dollars that they couldn't spend
like lunar geology.
And, of course, you don't want to turn money back.
You've got to spend it.
So Roger Moore found this out, and I went to Ernie Liddell, and he went to Orrin, and we said, look, we found a way to spend this money.
And we couldn't get people to take the money, which is ridiculous.
Pete Orrin's going to kill me for this, but I told him back in January that if he can do what he says he's going to do with Clementine for the amount of money there's going to be hell to pay at NASA,
The reason I bring this up is there's a lot of talk about they're going to dismantle NASA and so forth.
And I don't know which side I'm on because I worked for NASA, worked at headquarters, but the Air Force paved my way through my Ph.D. and supported me at Aerospace Corporation.
Do you see any big changes?
Again, this is subjective, but you're not working for the agency anymore, so I don't even know if it will be in the book, but I'm curious.
One of the things that bothers me about Clementine is that everybody is touting it as to how wonderful a program you can do for a very little expense.
I told Gordon, I said, you can't even build a flight-qualified spectrograph for $55 million.
Okay.
The difficulty is they don't realize all the money that's been spent bringing everything up to the status it has today to be put into Clementine.
We could not start from scratch, like NASA has to do, and fly Clementine for the price that they're flying it for.
It's the fact that there's millions and millions and millions of them.
In fact, a hundred million.

I don't know how much into these specific instruments, but there's been a lot of money going into these things, which they're able to assemble relatively inexpensively and fly relatively inexpensively.
And I think it's very misleading.
Do you think NASA has a future?
I think it has a very good future.
I think itwell, let me back off for a moment.
Does it have the potential for a future?
The answer to that is yes.
There are many very good things you can do in space, and you can do it relatively
When I say relatively inexpensively, you don't have to spend $10 billion a year.
You might be able to get by for $4 billion a year.
You're not going to get by for a few hundred million dollars a year.
On the other hand, is NASA going to survive by budget, off the budget, Congress?
I don't know.
I think it has some real serious problems there.

From Fred Whipple and Gerard de Bacolor and down, the opinion that I've gotten so far from, I don't know, at least 30 people on the record is that NASA money was absolutely crucial to the rebirth of modern planetary astronomy.
Oh, absolutely.
There's no question about it.
It was planetary astronomy.
In fact, it was very strange.
Sitting in this desk, or not this desk, but the desk I had from 1964, I was planetary astronomy in the United States.
It was a very small field then, wasn't it?
You knew everybody.
No, but it grew.
And it's amazing to me today to meet people and say, hey, you are responsible.

You are responsible for me being what I am today, because it was the money that you gave in this grant to this institution that allowed me to have, you know, a postdoc or graduate student support or something else in planetary astronomy.
Not only that, but you realize that Hawaii, Texas, Arizona, there's a tremendous amount of research being done with instruments that NASA built.
We didn't physically build them, but we provided the funds for them, and they've been very beneficial.
I mean, it's absolutely amazing to me.
The community, the non-planetary infrared community, complained bitterly about the IRTF.
They still complain bitterly about the IRTF.
Their complaint now is they don't get enough time on it.
Okay.
But for a long time they complained bitterly because it was a waste of money as far as they could see, and while it might be useful for some planetary astronomers,
who didn't do decent science anyway, there was no good science could be done with that telescope.
Gee, there was one other question I wanted to ask.
